content: The "Immigration Backlog Reduction Act of 2011" allows for expedited removal of inadmissible arriving aliens. The Immigration Backlog Reduction Act of 2011 allows for expedited removal of inadmissible arriving aliens under certain conditions outlined in Section 235(b)(1)(A) of the Immigration and Nationality Act. The Immigration Backlog Reduction Act of 2011 allows for expedited removal of inadmissible arriving aliens under certain conditions outlined in Section 235(b)(1)(A) of the Immigration and Nationality Act. If an alien falls under 212(a)(6)(C) or 212(a)(7), they may be ordered removed from the United States without further hearing or review, unless they have been charged with a crime, pose a significant risk to national security, or express an intention to apply for asylum or fear of persecution after being in the US for less than 1 year. If an arriving alien is inadmissible under section 212(a)(6)(C) or 212(a)(7) and expresses intent to apply for asylum or fear of persecution, they may be subject to expedited removal under the Immigration Backlog Reduction Act of 2011. If an arriving alien expresses intent to apply for asylum or fear of persecution, they may be referred for an interview by an asylum officer if present in the US for less than 1 year. SEC. 3. EXPEDITED REMOVAL OF CRIMINAL ALIENS. Section 238 of the Immigration and Nationality Act is amended to allow expedited removal of criminal aliens from correctional facilities. The Secretary of Homeland Security can determine deportability and issue removal orders for criminal aliens. Section 240 of the Immigration and Nationality Act describes the criteria for an alien to be considered deportable based on criminal offenses. It includes conditions related to lawful admission status at the time of the offense. Additionally, subsection (c) is amended to refer to specific criteria for deportability rather than just being convicted of an aggravated felony.
